body.div:
Such was the history of my beloved cotta
gers. It struck ^impressed me deeply, – and ^ prom it fr I learned from it ^
^ the views
of social
life which
it developed to admire
their virtues & to deprecate the vices of mankind.
But crimes were distant But aAs yet I looked
upon crime as a distant evil; but forbene
volence& generosity were ever present
before me – and I ^ardentlylonged ^desired to make one ^inciting in me to desire to become an actor in the
busy scene where so many admirable
qualities were called forth and displayed.
But I in giving the histor an account
of the progress of my intellects, I must not
omit a circumstance that tookwhich occurred
place in the beginning of the month
of August of thatthe same year.
One night during my accustomed
visit to the neighbouring wood where
I collected my own food and brought
home firing for p my protectors, I found
on the ground a leathern portmanteau
containing several articles of dress & some
books. I se eagerly seized the prize&
returned with it to my hovel. The books
were fortunately written in the language
the elements
of which
I had learned at the cottage; they consisted
of "Paradise Lost" — a volume of Plutarchs
lives and the sSorrows of Werter – And these
I ^was delighted in the possessiniongof these treasures
which X
gave me
infiniteextreme
delight^ I could now continually study
and occupyexercise my mind upon ^themsehistories when my
friends were employed in their ordinary
concernsoccupations. I can hardly describe to you the
effect thatof these books had upon meproduced. They pro
duced in me an infinity of new images & ideas
that sometimes raised me to extacy but oftenormore
frequently sunk me to the lowest dejection. In the
Sorrows of Werter besides the interrest of its
simple and affecting story so many opinions are
canvassed and so many lights thrown upon what
had ^hitherto been
to me hitherto darkobscure subects that I found ^in it
a never end source of speculation. & astonishment. The
gentle and domestic manners it described com
bined with lofty sentiments, and feelings ^which had for their object something out of selfaccor
ded well with my experience among my pro
tectors. ^and with the wants which were for ever alive within my own bosom. But I thought Werter himself a more
divine being than I had ever beheld, –or imagined. His cha
racter contained no pretention but it sunk
deep – for he thought The disquisitions upon death
and suicide gave were calculated to fill me
with astonishment
wonder. – I did not pretend to
enter into the merits of the case yet I
einclined towards the opinion of the Hero
whose extinction I wept although I didwithout
precisely
not understanding it. As I read however I
applied much ^personally to myself ^ andown feelings & condition I found my
selfat the same tim e similar yet
^
at the same time strangely unlike the beings concerning whom
I read and who were my toto of whose conver
sation I was a listener – I sympathized
I pa with & partly understood them– but
I was unformed in mind. I was dependant
on none, & related to none – "The path of my
departure was free"! and there was none
to lament my extinctionmy annihilation – My person
was hideous and my stature gigantic – What
did this mean? Who was I? What was I?
Whence
did I come?
What was
my destination? these questions continually recurred but I
was unable to solve them
The volume of Plutarchs lives which I
possessed contained the histories of the first
founders of the ancient republics– This book
had a far different effect upon me from
the letters Sorrows the letters of Werter. I learned
from that his Werter's g imaginations despondency & gloom; but Plutarch
taught me high thoughts—he elevated me above
m the wretched sphere of my own reflections
to admire & love the heroes of past ages. Yet
Many things I read surpassed my unterstanding
and knowledge ^experience I had a very t confused know
ledge of kingdoms & wide extents of country
mighty rivers and boundless seas. But I
was perfectly unacquainted with towns &
large
assemblegsassemblages of men. The cottagers wereof my protectors was was
the o only school inwherewhich I had studied human
nature — But this book threw a new light upon ^developed new & mightier scenes of action
it I read of men concerned in public
affairs governing their species — an or masser
cering their speceis. I felt the greatest ardour
for virtue rise within me and abhor
rence for vice
as far as I understood it the
signification of those terms relative as they
were only, as I applied them, to pleasure
and pain ^alone.. withInduced by these feelings it may be
I was of course led to admire peacable
lawgivers Numa, Solon & Lycurgus more than
Romulus and Theseus. The patriarchal lives
of my protectors induced im causedto a greater degree
these impressions ^to take a firm hold on my mind — perhaps if my first resid
ence
human introduction to
intercourse
withhumanity had been ^ withmade by a young soldier burning
for glory and slaughter I should have
been imbued with different sensations
But Paradise Lost Excited
in me different and far deeper
sensations
feelingsemotions –I read it as I didhad read the
other volumes which had fallen in
to my hands, as a true history. and It
excited
moved every feelingfeeling of wonder and
awe. I deeply lamented the fall
of AdamthatTthe picture of an omni
potent God warring with his crea
tures was capable of exciting – often
I ^often referred the several situations
as their similarity struck me to
my own. Like Adam I felt mywas
self
created
but I w apparently
desolate in my situation
as I had been had been
united by no link to any
other being of the
creationin existence but
his state was different from
mine in every other respect.
He had come forth from the
hands of God a perfect creature
happy & prosperousX
guarded by the spees
pecial care of his
creator. and–he wasallow
ed to converse &
acquire knowledge
from beings of a
superior nature– but I was
wretched helpless and alone. Oft
Many times I considered Satan
as my fitter mate for often
like him when I viewed the
bliss of my protectors the bitter
gall of envy rose within me.
But I would not disturb their
he Another circumstance
strengthened and confirmed these
feelings. I had soon a Soon affeaf
ter my arrival in the hovel I dis
covered some papers in one of the
pockets of the dress thatwhich I had taken
from your study. IAthad first I haddespised
neglected
them but now that I was able to decypher
the characters in them ^which they were written I began to decypher study them
with diligence. It was your journal of
the four la months that preceeded
my creation. It
you minutely des
cribed^in it these papers every step you took in the
progress of your work; and this ^history was
mingled with accounts of domestic
occurences. You doubtless well recollect
these papers– Here they are – Every
thing is toldrelatedi in them^
^which bears
reference to
my accursed ori
gin.& everythe whole detail of thatdisgus
ting circumstanceseries of horrorsdisgusting circumstances which produced it is set in view;
the minutest description is given of my
odious & loathsome person. is X
Xgiven in language
which painted your
own horrors, &has
tracedconveyed them to
has rendered mine
ineffaceable.. I
sickened as I read – the papers. One
Hateful day when I received life, I
exclaimed in agony— Cursed cCreator
Why did you form a monster
so hideous that even you turned
from me in disgust. God in pity made
man beautiful & alluring – I am
more hateful to the sight than
the bitter apples of Hell to the taste
Satan has his companions, fellow
devils, to admire and encourage
him. but I am solitary & detested
Such ^These were my reflections in my
hours of despondency & solitude but
when I contemplated the virtues of
the cottagers. Their amiable & benevolent
dispositions I persuaded myself that X
XWhen they ^should be
came acquainted with
my admiration of their
virtues
they would pity me and overlook
my personal deformity when they
should know my admiration of
their virtues.Yes I ^ was mad enough to ^ put my
trust in my own intentions and to
Could they turn from their door
one however monstrous, who solici
ted their compassion & friendship?
I resolved at least not to despair
but in every way to fit myself
for an interview which would
descide my fate. I wish I postponed
this attempt for some months longer for the
importance attached to it'ssuccess inspired
me with a ^dreadfor it's successlest it should not succeed
that I in vain endeavoured to
surmount. Besides I found that
my understanding improved so much
with every days experience that
I that I was unwilling to attempt
commence this attemptsundertaking untill
a few more months should have
added to my des wisdom
ManySeveral changes in the mean
time took place in the cottage
the presence of MaimounaSafie diffused
happiness among its inhabitants and
also as I soon perceived more plenty
and I also found that a greater g degree
of plenty & en reigned there – Felix &
and Agatha spent more time
in amusement ^ and& conversation they and were now also
assisted in their labours by servants
They were notdid not appear rich but they were
contented & happy. Such were their fee
lings^were serene & peaceful, while Imine became every day more
unhappy
miserable – encrease of knowledge only shewed
discovered to me more plainly ^clearly what a wretched outcast
I was. I cherished hope it is true but
it vanished when I beheld my person re
flectedbyinthe water or even my shadow
in the moonshine —I endeavoured to hush
crush these fears and to fortify myself for the
trial which in a few months I resolved
to undergo; and sometimes I allowed my
thoughts unchecked by reason to ramble
in the fields of Paradise &to fan dared
to fancy amiable & lovely beings sym
pathizing with my feelings and cheeri
ng my d gloom — Their angelic cont
countenances breathed smiles of consola
tion — But it was all a dream – No
Eve waited on soothed my sorrows
or shared my thoughts. I was alone.
I remembered Adams supplication to
his creator but where was mine?
He had abbandoned me and in the
bitterness of my heart I cursed him.
Autumn passed thus and with
surpise & grief I saw the leaves decay
& fall,
And nature again assume
the barren & bleak appearance
it had when I first beheld the
woods and the lovely moon. I
did not heed the coldbleakness of the weatherBy my consti
tutionI was more fitted for thatthis sufferance
of cold than heat. But my only joys were
were the sight of flowers and birds
and all the gay apparel of summer
but
and when those deserted me & the
days became shorter I turned with
more attention towards the cottagers
Their happiness was ^not decreased by Tthe absence of summer – They loved
and sympathized with one another
and theirhappiness ^joys depending on
each other were not hurtinterrupted by the
casualties that took place around
them — The more I saw of them
the greater became my desire to
claim their protection & kindness.
My heart yearned to beco be ^known and loved
by these amiable creatures to see
their sweet looks directed towards
me in kindness – I dared not think
that they would turn them from me
with disdain or horror – The poor
that stopt at their door were
never driven away –And I I asked
it is true for greater treasures
that a little food or rest I required
kindness & sympathy but I ^did not
believe my self utterly unworthy
of it
Chap. 7
The seasonwinter advanced and it was now about aand an entire revolution of the
year ^seasons had taken place since I awoke into life.– and I thenat
thattime My attention ^at this time was now solely
directed towards my plan of introducing
myself into the cottage of my protectors. I revol
ved many projects but that on which I
finally fixed was to enter their dwelling when
the blind old man wasshould be alone. My voice
although harsh had nothinkg terrible in
it.and I had sagacity enough to discover
that the unnatural hideousness of my person
was the chief object of horror am with those
who had formerly beheld me:–my voice al
though harsh, had nothing terrible in
it. I thought therefore that if in the absence
of his children I could gain the goodwill
of the old De Lacey I might by his means be
tolerated by the my younger protectors.
One clear One day when the sun
shone on the red leaves that strewed
the ground, and all diffused cheerfulness
although it denied warmth MaimounaSafie
Agatha and Felix set out on a long country
walk and the old man at his own desire
was left alone in the cottage. When his chil
dren had departed he took up his guitar &
played ver several mournful but sweet
airs:that I had seldom ^more sweet & mournful that I had ever heard him play
before. At first his countenance was illumi
nated with pleasure but as he continued thought
fullness and sadness succeeded and laying down
the instrument he sat absorbed
in reflection.
My heart beat quick. This
was the hour & moment of trial
which was to ^would decide my fea hopes
or
I quitted my hovel with trem
